articles.headline: Chinese Swimmers Twice Tested Positive for Drugs. They Kept on Swimming.
articles.snippet: Three athletes who failed drug tests before the 2021 Olympics had tested positive for a banned drug several years earlier. They were not suspended in either incident.
articles.abstract: Three athletes who failed drug tests before the 2021 Olympics had tested positive for a banned drug several years earlier. They were not suspended in either incident.
articles.lead_paragraph: After the revelation in April that 23 elite Chinese swimmers had tested positive for a banned substance months before the last Summer Olympic Games, China and the global antidoping authority vigorously defended their decisions to allow them to compete in the Games in 2021. The swimmers, they insisted, had not been doping.
articles.byline: By Michael S. Schmidt and Tariq Panja

articles.headline: How Jeff Bezos Is Trying to Fix The Washington Post
articles.snippet: The Amazon founder has expressed his support to Will Lewis, the C.E.O., who has faced widespread criticism this month.
articles.abstract: The Amazon founder has expressed his support to Will Lewis, the C.E.O., who has faced widespread criticism this month.
articles.lead_paragraph: When The Washington Post’s staff gathered in the newsroom in early May to celebrate winning three Pulitzer Prizes, one person was conspicuously absent: Will Lewis, the company’s publisher and chief executive.
articles.byline: By Benjamin Mullin and Katie Robertson

articles.headline: For Gay Catholics and Supporters, a ‘Sense of Whiplash’ Over Pope’s Reported Use of Slur
articles.snippet: Pope Francis, noted for his outreach to gay Catholics, has been described as using an offensive Italian expression for gay men twice in recent weeks.
articles.abstract: Pope Francis, noted for his outreach to gay Catholics, has been described as using an offensive Italian expression for gay men twice in recent weeks.
articles.lead_paragraph: This was the pope who asked, “Who am I to judge?” in response to a question about gay priests in 2013. He announced last year that he would allow priests to bless same-sex couples, defying conservative critics in the Roman Catholic Church. And he apologized only weeks ago, in a statement from the Vatican, for using an offensive Italian term for gay men at a conference of bishops.

articles.headline: Not Your Average Flea Market: At La Pulga de Alamo, Stars Are Born
articles.snippet: Every weekend, a flea market in Alamo, Texas, transforms from a Latino shopping mecca into a dance floor. The locals’ colorful moves have drawn fans around the world.
articles.abstract: Every weekend, a flea market in Alamo, Texas, transforms from a Latino shopping mecca into a dance floor. The locals’ colorful moves have drawn fans around the world.
articles.byline: By Edgar Sandoval and Verónica Gabriela Cárdenas

articles.headline: As War Drags On, Gazans More Willing to Speak Out Against Hamas
articles.snippet: Ordinary Gazans are bearing the brunt of the 8-month Israeli military onslaught on the territory and many blame the Palestinian armed faction for starting the war.
articles.abstract: Ordinary Gazans are bearing the brunt of the 8-month Israeli military onslaught on the territory and many blame the Palestinian armed faction for starting the war.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Oct. 7, as the Hamas-led attack on Israel was unfolding, many Palestinians took to the streets of Gaza to celebrate what they likened to a prison break and saw as the sudden humiliation of an occupier.
articles.byline: By Raja Abdulrahim and Iyad Abuheweila

articles.headline: Washington Post Publisher and Incoming Editor Are Said to Have Used Stolen Records in Britain
articles.snippet: Years before becoming The Post’s publisher, Will Lewis assigned an article based on stolen phone records, a former reporter said.
articles.abstract: Years before becoming The Post’s publisher, Will Lewis assigned an article based on stolen phone records, a former reporter said.
articles.lead_paragraph: The publisher and the incoming editor of The Washington Post, when they worked as journalists in London two decades ago, used fraudulently obtained phone and company records in newspaper articles, according to a former colleague, a published account of a private investigator and an analysis of newspaper archives.
articles.byline: By Justin Scheck and Jo Becker

articles.headline: The Tasty New Challenge to Venezuela’s Autocrats: ‘Freedom Empanadas’
articles.snippet: After the Hernández sisters served breakfast to an opposition leader, the government shut down their restaurant. Then came an outpouring of support.
articles.abstract: After the Hernández sisters served breakfast to an opposition leader, the government shut down their restaurant. Then came an outpouring of support.
articles.lead_paragraph: A car pulled up recently outside a modest restaurant in the state of Guárico in Venezuela’s sprawling savanna. The driver shouted from behind the wheel: “Are you the ones whose business was closed by the government? I want a picture with you!”
articles.byline: By Isayen Herrera, Julie Turkewitz, Sheyla Urdaneta and Adriana Loureiro Fernandez

articles.headline: The Resistance to a New Trump Administration Has Already Started
articles.snippet: An emerging coalition that views Donald J. Trump’s agenda as a threat to democracy is laying the groundwork to push back if he wins in November, taking extraordinary pre-emptive actions.
articles.abstract: An emerging coalition that views Donald J. Trump’s agenda as a threat to democracy is laying the groundwork to push back if he wins in November, taking extraordinary pre-emptive actions.
articles.lead_paragraph: Opponents of Donald J. Trump are drafting potential lawsuits in case he is elected in November and carries out mass deportations, as he has vowed. One group has hired a new auditor to withstand any attempt by a second Trump administration to unleash the Internal Revenue Service against them. Democratic-run state governments are even stockpiling abortion medication.
articles.byline: By Charlie Savage, Reid J. Epstein, Maggie Haberman and Jonathan Swan

articles.headline: China’s Lust for Durian Is Creating Fortunes in Southeast Asia
articles.snippet: Demand for the fruit, known for its rich taste and intense smell, has reshaped parts of Southeast Asia, where it has long been a staple.
articles.abstract: Demand for the fruit, known for its rich taste and intense smell, has reshaped parts of Southeast Asia, where it has long been a staple.
articles.lead_paragraph: Before he started a company 15 years ago selling the world’s smelliest fruit, Eric Chan had a well-paying job writing code for satellites and robots. His family and friends were puzzled when he made the career change.
articles.byline: By Thomas Fuller and Gabriela Bhaskar

articles.headline: Coming to a City Near You: A Cricket Stadium?
articles.snippet: Backers of the sport are negotiating leases and approvals for venues across the United States.
articles.abstract: Backers of the sport are negotiating leases and approvals for venues across the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: Four years ago, after officials in Grand Prairie, Texas, were pitched an idea to turn the city’s underused minor league ballpark into a stadium for cricket, the city’s manager, Bill Hills, thumbed through a copy of “Cricket for Dummies.”
articles.byline: By Patrick Sisson and Desiree Rios

articles.headline: In a Digital Age, High-End Outdoors Magazines Are Thriving in Print
articles.snippet: Titles like Adventure Journal, Mountain Gazette, Summit Journal and Ori are aimed at “people who just don’t want to be on their phones anymore.”
articles.abstract: Titles like Adventure Journal, Mountain Gazette, Summit Journal and Ori are aimed at “people who just don’t want to be on their phones anymore.”
articles.lead_paragraph: In an ordinary industrial building off a busy Orange County street, a Seussian contraption, nearly 100 feet long, clattered to life. The room filled with the hum and squeaks of belts and machinery. There was the smell of hot glue.

articles.headline: Inside the Chechen Units Helping to Fight Russia’s War
articles.snippet: After hundreds of years of enmity with Russia, Chechens are deploying to Ukraine to fight Moscow’s war.
articles.abstract: After hundreds of years of enmity with Russia, Chechens are deploying to Ukraine to fight Moscow’s war.
articles.lead_paragraph: A hulking military transport plane roared onto the tarmac at the main airfield in Grozny, the capital of the Chechen Republic in southeastern Russia, and a group of 120 volunteer fighters heading for Ukraine clambered aboard.
articles.byline: By Nanna Heitmann and Neil MacFarquhar

articles.headline: As N.B.A. TV Deal Nears, Warner Bros. Discovery Is on the Outside
articles.snippet: The company’s TNT channel and the N.B.A. have long been inextricably linked, but that may end after next season. Plus, Charles Barkley is retiring.
articles.abstract: The company’s TNT channel and the N.B.A. have long been inextricably linked, but that may end after next season. Plus, Charles Barkley is retiring.
articles.lead_paragraph: Warner Bros. Discovery executives thought they had given the National Basketball Association a proposal it would accept.
articles.byline: By Tania Ganguli, Kevin Draper and Nicole Sperling

articles.headline: Toyota Investors Challenge Scion’s Grip at a ‘Critical Juncture’
articles.snippet: Akio Toyoda ran Toyota for 14 years before handing the reins to a new C.E.O. last year, but some have grown concerned about the control he still wields.
articles.abstract: Akio Toyoda ran Toyota for 14 years before handing the reins to a new C.E.O. last year, but some have grown concerned about the control he still wields.
articles.lead_paragraph: During his long tenure as chief executive, Akio Toyoda led Toyota Motor to the top of the car industry.

articles.headline: How A.I. Is Revolutionizing Drug Development
articles.snippet: In high-tech labs, workers are generating data to train A.I. algorithms to design better medicine, faster. But the transformation is just getting underway.
articles.abstract: In high-tech labs, workers are generating data to train A.I. algorithms to design better medicine, faster. But the transformation is just getting underway.
articles.lead_paragraph: The laboratory at Terray Therapeutics is a symphony of miniaturized automation. Robots whir, shuttling tiny tubes of fluids to their stations. Scientists in blue coats, sterile gloves and protective glasses monitor the machines.
articles.byline: By Steve Lohr and Spencer Lowell

articles.headline: Can A.I. Answer the Needs of Smaller Businesses? Some Push to Find Out.
articles.snippet: Artificial intelligence tools like ChatGPT are finding widest use at big companies, but there is wide expectation that the impact will spread.
articles.abstract: Artificial intelligence tools like ChatGPT are finding widest use at big companies, but there is wide expectation that the impact will spread.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Nashville Area Chamber of Commerce has convened an annual meeting of local business leaders since the 1800s, but the most recent gathering had a decidedly modern theme: artificial intelligence.

articles.headline: ‘A Hellscape’: Dire Conditions in Gaza Leave a Multitude of Amputees
articles.snippet: Access to medical care and even clean water is limited, and the risk of infection is high, making it difficult for patients to get follow-up surgeries, prosthetics and rehabilitation.
articles.abstract: Access to medical care and even clean water is limited, and the risk of infection is high, making it difficult for patients to get follow-up surgeries, prosthetics and rehabilitation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bleeding and crying, Dr. Hani Bseso’s teenage niece Ahed called out for him as she slipped in and out of consciousness.
articles.byline: By Hiba Yazbek, Bilal Shbair, Cassandra Vinograd and Abu Bakr Bashir

articles.headline: How Crypto Money Is Poised to Influence the Election
articles.snippet: The industry’s political awakening — and enormous pool of cash — is already affecting high-profile races across the country.
articles.abstract: The industry’s political awakening — and enormous pool of cash — is already affecting high-profile races across the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ryan Selkis, a cryptocurrency executive, was eating dinner at Mar-a-Lago last month when he got an unexpected invitation: Former President Donald J. Trump wanted him to come to the stage and say a few words.
articles.byline: By David Yaffe-Bellany, Erin Griffith and Theodore Schleifer
